data.fullName: Emmett Till and Mamie Till-Mobley National Monument
data.description: In 1955, 14-year-old Emmett Till traveled to Money, Mississippi, to visit relatives. He was kidnapped, tortured, and murdered after reportedly whistling at a white woman. His mother, Mamie Till-Mobley, insisted on an open-casket funeral near their hometown of Chicago. Her brave decision let the world see the racist violence inflicted upon her son and set the Civil Rights Movement into motion.
data.directionsInfo: Emmett Till and Mamie Till-Mobley National Monument contains sites in Sumner and Glendora, Mississippi, and Chicago, Illinois.

addresses.line1: Emmett Till and Mamie Till-Mobley National Monument Headquarters

data.description: The Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail winds nearly 4,900 miles through the homelands of more than 60 Tribal nations. It follows the historic outbound and inbound routes of the Lewis and Clark Expedition of 1803-1806 from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania to the Pacific Ocean. Follow the trail to find the people, places, and stories that make up the complex legacy of the expedition.
data.directionsInfo: Lewis & Clark National Historic Trail Headquarters Visitor Center is located inside DOI, National Park Service, Interior Region 3,4,5 Office. We are right on the Missouri River next to the Bob Kerrey Pedestrian Bridge in downtown Omaha, NE.

operatingHours.description: Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center is located on the Missouri River in Omaha, Nebraska.
operatingHours.name: Visitor Center Hours

data.weatherInfo: In winter, watch for ice on trails and sidewalks. In summer, make sure to drink plenty of water and wear sunscreen on hot days. Keep in mind the Trail covers 16 states, use www.weather.gov to look up the specific area you plan to visit.
data.name: Lewis & Clark

data.description: Abraham Lincoln believed in the ideal that everyone in America should have the opportunity to improve their economic and social condition. Lincoln’s life was the embodiment of that idea. We know him as the sixteenth president but he was also a spouse, parent, and neighbor who experienced the same hopes, dreams, and challenges of life that are still experienced by many people today.
data.directionsInfo: The Visitor Center is located at 426 South Seventh Street. The 4-block Lincoln Home Neighborhood is open to pedestrians and closed to vehicles.

operatingHours.description: The Visitor Center is open 9:00 AM to 5:00 PM. Here, visitors are able to reserve tickets, get site orientation, and view the park film. The visitor center is your go to place for information and accessibility needs and serves as the location for bathrooms, water refill station, and souvenirs/gifts.
operatingHours.name: Lincoln Home Visitor Center & Exhibit Homes

operatingHours.description: While the Visitor Center and Exhibit Homes have specific hours, visitors are free to walk the Lincoln Neighborhood and park grounds between the hours of 6:00 AM and 11:00 PM year round.
operatingHours.name: Park Grounds and Lincoln Neighborhood

images.title: Lincoln Home Draped in Bunting
images.altText: 2 story tan house with green shutters. Red, white, and blue striped bunting draped below its fence
images.caption: The original home where Abraham Lincoln lived before his presidency still stands and welcomes visitors to explore Lincoln's pre-presidential legacy.

images.title: Lincoln Home National Historic Site Visitor Center
images.altText: One story brick building with plants and shrubs.
images.caption: Information, restrooms, tour tickets, and park films are all available at the Lincoln Home visitor center.

images.title: Harriet Dean House
images.altText: 2 story brown house with dark green shutters and white fence.
images.caption: The first floor of the Dean House has exhibits focusing on changes in the Lincoln Home and family over the years.

images.title: Arnold House
images.altText: 1 story small gray house with stairs leading up to door.
images.caption: Exhibits in the Arnold House explore historic preservation of the neighborhood

images.title: Wayside Exhibits Along 8th Street
images.altText: Graveled road with wooden boardwalks. Waist-high wayside exhibits next to boardwalks.
images.caption: Explore the stories of Lincoln's neighborhood by reading the outdoor wayside exhibits are scattered along 8th street.

images.title: Heirloom Garden
images.altText: Garden with green plants surrounded by white picket fence
images.caption: The heirloom garden in the Dean House backyard grows heirloom vegetables in the summer and autumn.

data.weatherInfo: Temperatures at our site can range from 0°F (-18°C) in the winter to 95°F (35°C) or warmer in the summer. Summers can be very humid, with both intense sun, rainstorms, and thunderstorms. Winter sees clear skies as well as snow. Please dress appropriate for potential weather conditions. We recommend wearing shoes comfortable for walking.
data.name: Lincoln Home

data.description: Explore the Mormon Pioneer National Historic Trail across five states to see the 1,300-mile route traveled by Mormons who fled Nauvoo, Illinois, to the Great Salt Lake Valley in 1846-1847.
data.directionsInfo: The Mormon Pioneer National Historic Trail crosses five states following the route the Pioneer Company of 1846-1847 established from Nauvoo, Illinois, to Salt Lake City, Utah, covering about 1,300 miles.

operatingHours.description: The Mormon Pioneer National Historic Trail is not a clearly marked hiking trail. Instead it is a corridor that passes through communities, urban areas, public lands, and Wilderness. The route travels across a variety of land ownerships and management, including private land. Each location varies as to the hours of operation and access. Please contact individual trail sites before your visit for more information.
operatingHours.name: Mormon Pioneer National Historic Trail

images.title: Echo Canyon, Utah
images.altText: Red cliffs line a highway as seen from a high point with grass in the foreground.
images.caption: Echo Canyon on the way from Wyoming to Salt Lake City, Utah is both beautiful and historic.

images.title: Brigham Young grave, Utah
images.altText: A bronze plaque with description on a metal fence surrounding Brigham Young's grave.
images.caption: Brigham Young's grave lies in the heart of downtown Salt Lake City, Utah

images.title: Monument Rock, Utah.
images.altText: Red rock monolith in a rocky canyon
images.caption: Monument Rock in Echo Canyon, Utah.

images.title: Joseph & Emma Smith House, Nauvoo, Illinois
images.altText: A large, white, two-story historic wood home with a red roof and white picket fence.
images.caption: Joseph & Emma Smith  House in Nauvoo, Illinois.

images.title: Mormon Pioneer Trail in Utah
images.altText: A hiking trail with a trail sign.
images.caption: There are places you can hike on the historic trail!

data.weatherInfo: Due to the length of the Mormon Pioneer National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Check out the forecast with the National Weather Service and search for the area you'd like to visit: weather.gov
data.name: Mormon Pioneer

multimedia.title: Carthage Jail - Place to visit on the Mormon Pioneer National Historic Trail

data.description: To a casual observer, New Philadelphia looked like a typical Illinois pioneer town. But a closer look revealed a unique and racially diverse community. New Philadelphia was the first US town platted and registered by an African American. A formerly enslaved man, Free Frank McWorter, founded New Philadelphia in 1836 and purchased freedom for himself and 15 family members.
data.directionsInfo: New Philadelphia National Historic Site is in rural western Illinois between the Mississippi and Illinois rivers near Interstate 72. The site can be reached by turning onto 306th Lane from County Highway 2. An informational kiosk is immediately on the left after turning onto 306th Lane. The small city of Barry lies two miles west and has the nearest services. Hannibal, Missouri, is 27 miles west. Springfield, Illinois, is 76 miles east. St. Louis lies about 115 miles south.

operatingHours.description: The site is open to the public with no scheduled operating hours.
operatingHours.name: Operating Hours

images.title: Perseverance and Freedom on the Illinois Frontier
images.altText: A grassy field surrounded by forest under a sunny sky with large white clouds.
images.caption: View of New Philadelphia National Historic Site on a sunny day.

images.title: Kiosk
images.altText: Four interpretive panels mounted under a covered, open-sided kiosk overlooking a prairie landscape.
images.caption: A kiosk houses several informational panels at New Philadelphia National Historic Site.

images.title: Walking Tour
images.altText: A mowed path through prairie. There are numbered signs along the trail.
images.caption: Visitors can take a self-guided ¼-mile-long walking tour of the site using an augmented virtual reality app managed by the New Philadelphia Association. The app is available to download for electronic handheld devices, cost-free, at the kiosk.

images.credit: Courtesy of Gerald McWorter and Kate Williams McWorter.
images.title: Schoolchildren
images.altText: Twenty children of mixed ages and genders posing for the camera in front of a schoolhouse.
images.caption: Schoolchildren at the New Philadelphia School, October 1925.

images.credit: Courtesy of Pamela and Sheena Franklin
images.title: Lucy McWorter
images.altText: Historic black and white photo of an African American woman seated looking past the camera.
images.caption: Lucy McWorter, Free Frank McWorter’s wife, 1800s.

data.weatherInfo: Temperatures at our site can range from 0°F (-18°C) in the winter to 95°F (35°C) or warmer in the summer. Summers can be very humid, with intense sun, rainstorms, thunderstorms possible. Snow and occasional blizzard conditions are possible in the winter. Please dress appropriately for potential weather conditions and plan ahead.
data.name: New Philadelphia

data.description: In a growing Chicago neighborhood, diverse people and stories intertwined. All were seeking opportunity. Some succeeded. Others were limited—by race, gender, or economic status. Their stories came together in Pullman, a planned industrial community famed for its urban design and architecture.

emailAddresses.description: Email will be answered within 3-5 business days.

data.directionsInfo: The Administration Clock Tower Building Visitor Center is located at the corner of 111th Street and S. Cottage Grove Avenue. The parking lot entrance on 111th Street (DO NOT drive through the historic stone worker's gate entrance).

exceptions.name: Birthday of Martin Luther King Jr.

operatingHours.description:
Pullman National Historical Park is a living, historic neighborhood composed of primarily private residences. Due to it being an active neighborhood just as in any other urban area, visitors are free to explore whenever they feel comfortable. 

The Administration Clock Tower Building Visitor Center is open to the public.
operatingHours.name: Administration Clock Tower Building Visitor Center

images.title: Pullman Clocktower on sunny day
images.altText: front of clocktower taken looking up  with blue sky, sunny
images.caption: The iconic Pullman clocktower building is one of the central buildings of Pullman National Monument.

images.title: Clock Tower and Administration Building
images.altText: Clock Tower and Administration Building
images.caption: Built in 1880 for the rail car construction factory and executive offices of Pullman's Palace Car Company, this building complex was one of the most beautiful industrial landscapes in America.

images.title: Historic Administration Building
images.altText: Historic Administration Building
images.caption: Administration Building

images.title: Hotel Florence Building
images.altText: Hotel Florence Building in Fall.
images.caption: The Hotel Florence opened on November 1, 1881 as the hospitality showcase for visitors to George Pullman's "perfect town" of Pullman. The hotel was named for George's favorite daughter, Florence.

images.title: American Flag
images.altText: American flag flying on front porch.
images.caption: The Pullman district also benefits from a diverse and proud residential community.

images.title: Clock Tower and Administration Building
images.altText: Clock Tower and Administration Building with a walkway leading up to the front of it.
images.caption: Built in 1880 for the rail car construction factory and executive offices of Pullman's Palace Car Company

data.weatherInfo: The park lies in a humid continental zone with a generally temperate climate. Chicago winters are mildly cold with average temperatures around 26 degrees (F). Summers are hot and humid with an average temperature around 72 degrees (F). Average annual total rainfall is about 36". Snowfall in the winter is moderate with an average total snowfall of about 38".
data.name: Pullman

data.description: In August 1908, a large White mob attacked the Black community in Springfield, Illinois. Rioters destroyed homes and businesses and lynched two men. The event led to the founding of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP). Today, archeological evidence gives a rare glimpse into a community devastated by the race riots of the early 20th century.
data.directionsInfo: Springfield 1908 Race Riot National Monument is a new national park located in central Springfield, Illinois. No facilities or services are available. The park is currently surrounded by a construction project and visiting is not advised.

images.credit: Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture
images.title: Illinois State Militia
images.altText: Historic photo of militia members standing in the remains of a burned building.
images.caption: The Illinois State Militia stands in the burned home of a Black resident at the corner of 9th Street and Madison in Springfield.

images.credit: Collection of the Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture
images.title: Destroyed Home at 9th and Madison Streets
images.altText: Historic photo of two people using a hose to extinguish a burning building.
images.caption: Two people attempt to extinguish a burning building in 1908.

images.title: View of the Park Today
images.altText: A narrow grassy lot surrounded by fence.
images.caption: View of Springfield 1908 Race Riot National Monument Today

data.weatherInfo: Summers in Illinois are hot and humid. Winters can be cold and windy.
data.name: Springfield 1908 Race Riot

data.fullName: Trail Of Tears National Historic Trail
data.description: Remember and commemorate the survival of the Cherokee people, forcefully removed from their homelands in Georgia, Alabama, and Tennessee to live in Indian Territory, now Oklahoma. They traveled by foot, horse, wagon, or steamboat in 1838-1839.
data.directionsInfo: You can visit many of the sites along the Trail of Tears National Historic Trail over the 2,200+ mile route that crosses 9 states.

operatingHours.description: OPERATING HOURS VARY FROM SITE TO SITE. There are many historic sites, museums, and parks (federal, state, and local) along the Trail of Tears in Tennessee, North Carolina, Georgia, Alabama, Kentucky, Illinois, Arkansas, Missouri, or Oklahoma for you to visit. Please contact individual sites for more information by going to Plan Your Visit and selecting Places To Go or Passport Program, where sites are listed by state, and there is an interactive map to search for sites.
operatingHours.name: Trail of Tears National Historic Trail

addresses.line2: Trail of Tears National Historic Trail
Trail of Tears National Historic Trail

images.title: Chieftain's Museum, Rome, Georgia
images.altText: large white house, green lawn, two trees in front
images.caption: The museum tells the story of Major Ridge, the influential Ridge family including prominent son John Ridge, Cherokee history, and the Trail of Tears, as well as subsequent history of the home and region.

images.title: Brown's Ferry Tavern, Chattanooga, Tennessee
images.altText: structure in the background with large chimney on the end; signs saying Brown's Ferry Tavern
images.caption: Cherokee leader John Brown, who owned 640 acres in this area, ordered the construction of Browns Ferry Tavern in 1803. In 1838, the road running past this structure was the route by which several Cherokee detachments were removed to present-day Oklahoma.

images.title: Mantle Rock Preserve, Joy, Kentucky
images.altText: sunlight coming through trees with green leaves
images.caption: Thousands of Cherokee camped for weeks along the main (northern) route, near Mantle Rock, during the winter of 1838-39 as they waited for ice conditions in the Ohio River to allow a safe crossing.

images.title: Cherokee Retracement at Pea Ridge National Military Park, Garfield, Arkansas
images.altText: dozens of people walk a section of the Trail of Tears, winter scene, trees with no leaves
images.caption: The Pea Ridge National Military Park encompasses 4,300 acres and features a visitor center, museum, self-guided tours, reconstructed Elkhorn Tavern, and a retracement trail along a 2.5-mile original route segment of the Trail of Tears.

images.title: Grave Stone of William Adair, Stilwell, Oklahoma
images.altText: gravestone with words etched, green grass
images.caption: When the Cherokee arrived at their prescribed disbandment depot in Oklahoma, settlements sprang up nearby. There was a depot at the Adair's farm near present-day Stilwell, Oklahoma.

images.title: Crabb Abbott Farm, Grantsburg, Illinois
images.altText: Two people walk a remnant of the Trail of Tears. Spring setting with green leafed trees.
images.caption: Crabb Abbott Farm has segments of the Northern Route, including the rock crossing and ford of Sugar Creek. These segments are contiguous with trail segments on the adjacent Shawnee National Forest.

data.weatherInfo: Due to the length of the Trail of Tears National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Check out the forecast with the National Weather Service and search for the area you'd like to visit: www.weather.gov
data.name: Trail Of Tears
